title: 114_hr3295
content: The Department of Justice's Office of Justice Programs is appropriated $140,000,000 for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance in fiscal year 2015. This includes funding for various programs such as the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. The additional $10,000,000 for Juvenile Justice Programs is allocated for community-based violence prevention initiatives, focusing on public health approaches to reduce shootings and violence. This funding is separate from the Department of Justice's Office of Justice Programs appropriations for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance, which includes various programs like the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program and veterans treatment courts. $30,000,000 additional funding for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, split into $15,000,000 for State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States for precursor chemicals and methamphetamine investigations, and $15,000,000 for statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States for investigative purposes. $15,000,000 in competitive grants for statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States to investigate illicit activities related to heroin and prescription opioids. The Small Business Administration received $4,000,000 for entrepreneurial development programs and $1,000,000 for business loans. The Department of Labor received $265,000,000 for training and employment services. The Department of Health and Human Services received funding for maternal and child health programs. The Department of Health and Human Services received $50,000,000 for the Healthy Start Initiative, and $10,000,000 for drug court grants. The Department of Housing and Urban Development received funding for the choice neighborhoods initiative. The Department of Housing and Urban Development received an additional $170,000,000 for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative under the Community Planning and Development fund. $500,000,000 allocated for emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds awarded to states, tribes, or local governments based on Secretary of Housing and Urban Development's discretion and criteria like racial or income levels. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development allocates $500,000,000 for distressed communities affected by violence or civil unrest. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage to address long-term recovery, infrastructure, and economic revitalization. Criteria for eligibility include racial or income segregation, low employment rates, poor-performing schools, infant mortality, vacant homes, and proximity to environmentally hazardous areas. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage to address long-term recovery, infrastructure, and economic revitalization in distressed areas. The Secretary will specify approval criteria within 45 days of enactment, with disapproval for plans not meeting criteria. Funds allocated are separate from non-emergency formula allocations. Grantees will receive training on grant management. The Secretary will provide grantees with training on grant management, including performance requirements and penalties in contracts. The Secretary may waive or specify alternative requirements for statutes or regulations, except for fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment, if good cause exists. Up to 30 percent of funds can be used for immediate community response and revitalization assistance. Up to $10,000,000 may be transferred for Program Office Salaries and Expenses or Department of Community Planning and Development. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include provisions for moving-to-work programs. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028, with certain conditions. Agencies must report financial data for policy evaluation. The Act designates each amount as an emergency requirement, subject to the President's subsequent designation and transmission to Congress. The Act is also known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
